descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Catalog description: Shear center, nonprismatic members, nonlinear materials, influence lines, Muller-Breslau Principle, approximate methods of analysis, energy methods, stiffness matrix, and computer methods of analysis

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: A course in structural analysis; CIV_ENG 221-0

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
To extend the concepts learned in the first course in theory of structures (Civ_Env 221). Both classical and computer tools will be incorporated and complemented each other in the course. Experimentation using strain gages to measure structural responses will be compared with theoretical analysis presented in this course. At the end of this course, you will have the ability to:

1.analyze a structure with non-prismatic members using consistent displacement method using virtual work, slope deflection, and moment distribution;
2.determine the maximum design force using influence lines for floor systems and indeterminate structures;
3.analyze structures using commercial software and/or design worksheet to perform the analysis;
4.conduct experiments that could measure the response of a structure under static loads; and
5.perform preliminary analysis using approximate methods.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
CLASS SCHEDULE / Two 1 and 1/2 hour lectures and a one-hour required discussion section for 10 weeks per quarter.

COMPUTER USAGE / Use of MATLAB or spreadsheet software to solve and present graphically effects of parameter variation in structures Introduction to and use of the FRAME computer program

1. Review of shear and moment diagram for frames
2. Virtual Work
3. Slope Deflection
4. Moment Distribution
5. Stiffness matrix
6. Computer Software - use of typical commercial frame software to perform the analysis
7. Influence Lines
8. Approximate Analysis
9. Shear Center
10. Introduction to Plastic Analysis
11. Introduction to Stability
12. Introduction to Simple Plates
13. Experimentation

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades: course grade is composed of homework assignments, quizzes and tests, final exam, and experimentations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Beer and Johnston, Mechanics of Materials, 2nd ed., McGraw-Hill 1992.
